I haven't seen a good "bottom up" approach so I thought I would offer a cost-based approach rather than a trend based approach.  This approach may end up with a different answer because the consensus seems to be think that there is a lot of potential cost savings as a result of manufacturing improvements.  However, more than half of the cost of the battery is based on the price of the Annode & Cathode chosen. Here is my distribution of battery production cost (2016):
Cathode (Lithium):   28%
Anode (Graphite):    24%
Labor:                        15%
Assembly:                 12%
Electrolyte:                  8%
Separator:                   5% So you can see, that there are only a few areas where you can truly "squeeze" improvements at this point, and everything else is simply going to be the price of the Electrodes.   Now of course, the choice of Electrodes matters, and this probably where the real cost savings may take place Cathode Alternatives: Cost - Life (Market Share 2016)
LMO (LiMn2O4): Low - Low  (7%)
LCO (LiCoO2): Modest - Modest (32%)
NMC (LiNiMnCoO2): High - High (25%)
LFP (LiFePO4): High - Medium (20%)
NCA (LiNiCoAlO2): High - Medium (11%)
Other (eg, Titanate): (5%) So there is always a trade-off in terms of pricing and energy.  As such, the mix of market share will matter.  In many cases the transition to the lower cost LCO from NMC is really where most of the cost savings have spawned.  This trend will likely continue as NMC is great for "testing" but not good for actual production and profits. So that's the cost savings, but here's the catch, the cost of the components of LCO has grown exponentially.  Lithium for example has surged 200% from 2014, and 50% from 2016.   That is: $5k / ton in 2014, to $9k / ton at yr end 2016, to around $14k/ton today
Pricing has gotten so wild in lithium that Tesla is actually investing in a lithium mine outside of Nevada.   Similarly, Graphite is up 25% since the beginning of the year.   Putting all these components together suggests that pricing of for the electrodes of a battery produced today should be up roughly 20% (21.6% to be precise).   Using the 5/8th rule (i.e., total revenues/expenses resulting from growth between a prior period to today's prices only reflect 5/8th of the difference), suggest that for the year, pricing should be up 13.5%. This almost entirely wipes out the cost savings trend from the prior result.  Including a modest shift in market share to cheaper batteries (and the elimination of higher cost producers: e.g., Tesla Model 3) for production purposes, and the 16% cost savings trend, suggest that pricing should be down 13.5%.   This places the midpoint of the estimate at $249/Kwh, unfortunately right at the cusp of the upper limit.   ---------------------- 11 / 13 / 2017 Update ---------------

The number, claims the Economist in last week's issue, for 2016 was in the 130-200 per kWh range, which is strange. It also goes on to say that GM, for its Bolt, pays 145 per kWh to LG Chem, AND that Tesla claims even lower numbers.  It's important to note that there is an oversupply of Li-ion batteries (by about a third). All in all, I think the average, which is in qn here, will be higher than the Economist-quoted projections of sub-200 per kWh, but will be significantly lower than the 282 per kWh for 2016 per the Mack Institute.

I approached this somewhat differently, though I agree most of cost is materials so cost reduction will be demand driven with minimal changes in short-run supply (lithium prices go up with more demand, supply fixed in short-run).   The $282 price is the unweighted average of a measly 4 data-points given in the blog-posted data.  There is one estimate from either battery pack replacement costs or a company representative for 4 vehicles , Bolt, Model S, i3, and Nissan Leaf, 2 published by the same author, and 2 from industry analysts.  The things that could potentially affect next years "estimated average" which is not the same as "next year's actual average costs" are principally:
1) Tesla Model 3 is new big player and will likely get a "data point" and it will be lower than others (PR, reality, competition)
2) Whether the same individuals are reached to provide such estimates
3) Whether the numbers provided and published have any precision.  For example, Tesla could change the way they compute average costs reported to analysts via managerial accounting 101.
4) whether additional studies are published from alternative sources/methods. Given these things, I predict the 8-10% learning rate will continue.  However, year over year estimates provided by Tesla in 2015 and 2016 (from CEO and CTO to investors) show a 12.4% reduction at Tesla, which will represent the reduction of 2/5 expected measurements in next year's reports.  BMW showed a 22% reduction YOY from 2015-2014 which represents 1/5 of the measurements.  If I assume similar decreases reported for BMW and Tesla, and average 8% decreases for Nissan and Chevy (less expectation of major advances given less investments being made) I arrive at an average reported number of $224/kwh.   Assuming next years published reports will be from similar reports, the manufacturer representing sources have more incentive to report lower numbers than higher numbers, so I will skew accordingly.   This of course is not actually the industry's average cost, because each manufacturer is not producing the same quantities.  But given the question and study's methods, this is how I will answer.  Lots of analysis for somewhat questionable data in my opinion.  As an aside, somewhat lackluster depth of investigation for a Wharton institution, but I like the question and will play along.

Production costs for batteries are dominated by material costs, with labor (proxy for efficiency) at only about 20%.    I would contend evolution in design/production is the primary driver for future and past cost reductions, not "economy of scale".  Battery technology is fairly stable, dramatic breakthroughs are unlikely, and even more unlikely to be implemented at an industrial scale in this time frame. current Li battery technology for EV is probably in its 3dr or 4th generation, so they are fairly mature in design and production. Life span of a manufacturing generation is estimated at 6 years, with most production early in their generational life span.  So the production costs for current batteries is stable, with diminishing reductions in future costs (barring revolutionary new battery concepts).     Not sure if "industry average" is a weighted average (by production volume). But if it is then entry level EV's will suffer from low oil prices. Tipping the scale towards the Tesla "production" sales price (may not truly reflect production cost).

Maybe I was too enthusiastic in my first answer and definitely didn't do enough research. I am now going to assume that the rate of change remains constant and guess a 16% decline this year but also acknowledge that with Tesla ramping up mass production prices may fall faster.

Scaling factors are accelerating in 2017 for BEV.  Near term (like within 2017), I'd guess that cost decline will still follow the scatter plot from Wharton.  Long term, however, it is unclear how much more cost one can squeeze out.  Lithium is very mature tech and chemistry doesn't follow Moore's Law.  Furthermore, 60%-70% of the world's Cobalt is sourced from Congo, which is an unstable regime.  Worse, concentrated sources are prone to cartel-like manipulation.

There is plenty of Lithium available on Earth and large scale investment is continuing in Australia and other countries.  According to Wharton Business School, the cost of Lithium-Ion kilowatt hours has decreased at an average rate of 16% per year from 2007-2016.  The line-of-best fit on the Wharton scatter plot shows a linear decrease with few outlying data points.  According to Wharton, the current cost per kilowatt hour for Lithium-Ion battery packs is $282 and a 16% decrease would leave us at $237.  Even if a new and disruptive technology arrived, most large scale factories have set-up and already know what and how they are producing all of next year.
Continuing the 16% a year decline should put it in the  2330 to 245 range, but heavy demand from Tesla and GM and hybrids may start to have an effect anddrive prices lower into the 215 to 230 range.
